description.text: Pattern discovery in sets of unaligned protein sequences

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Fasta format. One file containing all the sequences. One sequence is specified by

one line starting with '>' in position 1 and then the name of the sequence, and some lines containing the sequence in upper or lower case. The end of a sequence is identified by looking for either the start of a new sequence or the end of the file.
xhtml:div.div:
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
>seq1 HLKSEDEMKASEDLKKHKKKGHHEAEIKPLAQSHATKHKIPVKYLEFIS SDLHAHKLRKRKLVKNMVL >seq2 VEVFISEDDLKRKLVKNMVLDKDNKQHMLPKAGDTVTNYTLLGLVLVLI WLIMQRKRKKKEDVSEENIQEIPKKELAASS

xhtml:div.label:
Minimum number of Sequences to Match (-CM)?
Set the minimum number of sequences to match a pattern. Pratt will only report patterns that match at least the chosen number of the sequences that you have input. Pratt will not allow you to choose a value higher than the number of sequences input.

Minimum Percentage of Sequences to Match (-C%)?
Set the minimum percentage of the input sequences that should match a pattern. If you set this to, say 80, Pratt will only report patterns matching at least 80 % of the sequences input.

Position in sequence (-PP)?
OFF Complete pattern match has to be in this area (complete) Pattern match has to start in this area (start)

fieldset.legend: Restriction File name (if PP not off) (-PF)?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This file contains lines to restrict pattern searches to certain regions in a sequence, say ACE2_YEAST:
>ACE2_YEAST (100,200)

xhtml:div.label:
Maximum Pattern Length (-PL)?
Allows you to set the maximum length of a pattern. The length of the pattern C-x(2,4)-[DE] is 1+4+1=6.

Maximum number of Pattern Symbols (-PN)?
Using this you can set the maximum number of symbols in a pattern. The pattern C-x(2,4)-[DE] has 2 symbols (C and [DE]).

Maximum number of consecutive x's (-PX)? [use example data]
Using this option you can set the maximum length of a wildcard.
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
x - 1 x(10) - 10 x(3,4) - 4
x - 1 x(10) - 10 x(3,4) - 4

Maximum number of flexible spacers (-FN)?
Using this option you can set the maximum number of flexible wildcards (matching a variable number of arbitrary sequence symbols). For instance x(2,4) is a flexible wildcard, and the pattern C-x(2,4)-[DE]-x(10)-F contains one flexible wildcard.

Maximum Flexibility (-FL)?
You can set the maximum flexibility of a flexible wildcard (matching a variable number of arbitrary sequence symbols). For instance x(2,4) and x(10,12) has flexibility 2, and x(10) has flexibility 0. Increasing FL will increase the time used by Pratt.

Maximum Flexibility Product (-FP)? [use example data]
Using option FP you can set an upper limit on the product of a flexibilities for a pattern. This is related to the memory requirements of the search, and increasing the limit, increases the memory usage. Some patterns and the corresponding product of flexibilities.
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
C-x(2,4)-[DE]-x(10)-F - (4-2+1)*(10-10+1)= 3 C-x(2,4)-[DE]-x(10-14)-F - (4-2+1)*(14-10+1)= 3*5= 15
C-x(2,4)-[DE]-x(10)-F - (4-2+1)*(10-10+1)= 3 C-x(2,4)-[DE]-x(10-14)-F - (4-2+1)*(14-10+1)= 3*5= 15

Input Pattern Symbol File? (-BI)?
Yes No
Using the B options (BN,BI,BF) on the menu you can control which pattern symbols will be used during the initial pattern search and during the refinement phase. The pattern symbols that can be used, are read from a file if the BI option is set, otherwise a default set will be used.
The default set has as the 20 first elements, the single amino acid symbols, and it also contains a set of ambiguous symbols, each containing amino acids that share some physio-chemical properties

fieldset.legend: Input Pattern Symbol File name (if BI on) (-BF)? [use example data]

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: In the file each symbol is given on a separate line concataining the letters that the symbol should match. For the example, only patterns with the symbols C and [DE] would be considered. During the initial search, pattern symbols corresponding to the first BN lines can be used.
default file is: Pratt.sets.big
xhtml:div.div:
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
C DE

xhtml:div.label:
Number of Pattern Symbols Initial Search (-BN)?
Increasing BN will slow down the search and increase the memory usage, but allow more ambiguous pattern symbols.

Scoring (-S)?
Information content (info) Minimum Description Length (mdl) Diversity calculated from a dendrogram (tree) Distances matrix (dist) Positive Predictive Value (ppv)
The S option allows you to control the scoring of patterns. There are five possible scoring schemes to be used:
info: patterns are scored by their information content as defined in (Jonassen et al, 1995). Note that a pattern's score is independent of which sequences it matches.
mdl: patterns are scored by a Minimum Description Length principle derived scoring scheme, which is related to the one above, but penalises patterns scoring few sequences vs. patterns scoring many. Parameters Z0 to Z3 are required when this scoring scheme is used.
tree: a pattern is scored higher if it contains more information and/or if it matches more diverse sequences. The sequence diversity is calculated from a dendrogram which has to be input.
dist: similar to the tree scoring, except a matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree. The matrix has to be input.
ppv: a measure of Positive Predictive Value - it is assumed that the input sequences constitute a family, and are all contained in the Swiss-Prot database. PPV measures how certain one can be that a sequence belongs to the family given that it matches the pattern.
For the last three scoring schemes (tree, dist, ppv), an input file is needed.

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
fieldset.legend: Tree File for Scoring equal to tree (-SF)

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
fieldset.legend: Distances File if Scoring equal to dist (-SF)?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: A matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree.

fieldset.legend: Swissprot file if Scoring equal to ppv (-SF)?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Default: uniprot_sprot databank.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Z0

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Z1

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Z2

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Z3

Pattern Graph from: (-G)?
Sequence (seq) Alignment (al) Query
If G is set to al or query, another option GF is required allowing the user to give the name of a file containing a multiple sequence alignment (in Clustal W format), or a query sequence in FastA format (without annotation). Only patterns consistent with the alignment/matching the query sequence will be considered.

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
fieldset.legend: Alignment file (if G set to al) (-GF)?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Alignment file must be in CLUSTALW format

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
fieldset.legend: Query sequence file (if G set query) (-GF)?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Query file must be in Fasta format

xhtml:div.label:
Search Greediness (-E)?
Using the E parameter you can adjust the greediness of the search. Setting E to 0 (zero), the search will be exhaustive. Increasing E increases the greediness, and decreases the time used in the search.

Pattern Refinement (-R)?
Yes No
When the R option is switched on, patterns found during the initial pattern search are input to a refinement algorithm where more ambiguous pattern symbols can be added. For instance the pattern C-x(4)-D might be refined to C-x-[ILV]-x-D-x(3)-[DEF]

Generalise ambiguous symbols (if Pattern Refinement on) (-RG)?
Yes No
If the RG option is switched on, then ambiguous symbols listed in the symbols file (or in the default symbol set -- see help for option B), are used. If RG is off, only the letters needed to match the input sequences are included in the ambiguous pattern positions.
For example, if [ILV] is a listed allowed symbol, and [IL] is not, [IL] can be included in a pattern if RG is off, but if RG is on, the full symbol [ILV] will be included instead.

PROSITE Pattern Format (-OP)?
Yes No
When switched on, patterns will be output in PROSITE style (for instance C-x(2,4)-[DE]). When switched off, patterns are output in a simpler consensus pattern style (for instance Cxx--[DE] where x matches exactly one arbitrary sequence symbol and - matches zero or one arbitrary sequence symbol).

Maximum number patterns (-ON)?
Set the maximum number of patterns to be found by Pratt

Maximum number Alignments (-OA)?
Set the max. nr of patterns for which Pratt is to produce an alignment of the sequence segments matching it.

Print Patterns in sequences (-M)?
Yes No
If the M option is set, then Pratt will print out the location of the sequence segments matching each of the (maximum 52) best patterns. The patterns are given labels A, B,...Z,a,b,...z in order of decreasing pattern score. Each sequence is printed on a line, one character per K-tuple in the sequence. If pattern with label C matches the third K-tuple in a sequence C is printed out. If several patterns match in the same K-tuple, only the best will be printed.

Ratio for printing (-MR)?
Sets the K value (ratio) used for printing the summary information about where in each sequence the pattern matches are found.

Print vertically (-MV)?
Yes No
If set, the output is printed vertically instead of horizontally, vertical output can be better for large sequence sets.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Fasta format. One file containing all the sequences. One sequence is specified by

one line starting with '>' in position 1 and then the name of the sequence, and some lines containing the sequence in upper or lower case. The end of a sequence is identified by looking for either the start of a new sequence or the end of the file.

Set the minimum number of sequences to match a pattern. Pratt will only report patterns that match at least the chosen number of the sequences that you have input. Pratt will not allow you to choose a value higher than the number of sequences input.
Set the minimum percentage of the input sequences that should match a pattern. If you set this to, say 80, Pratt will only report patterns matching at least 80 % of the sequences input.
This file contains lines to restrict pattern searches to certain regions in a sequence, say ACE2_YEAST:
>ACE2_YEAST (100,200)
Allows you to set the maximum length of a pattern. The length of the pattern C-x(2,4)-[DE] is 1+4+1=6.
Using this you can set the maximum number of symbols in a pattern. The pattern C-x(2,4)-[DE] has 2 symbols (C and [DE]).
Using this option you can set the maximum length of a wildcard.

Using this option you can set the maximum number of flexible wildcards (matching a variable number of arbitrary sequence symbols). For instance x(2,4) is a flexible wildcard, and the pattern C-x(2,4)-[DE]-x(10)-F contains one flexible wildcard.

You can set the maximum flexibility of a flexible wildcard (matching a variable number of arbitrary sequence symbols). For instance x(2,4) and x(10,12) has flexibility 2, and x(10) has flexibility 0. Increasing FL will increase the time used by Pratt.

Using option FP you can set an upper limit on the product of a flexibilities for a pattern. This is related to the memory requirements of the search, and increasing the limit, increases the memory usage. Some patterns and the corresponding product of flexibilities.

Using the B options (BN,BI,BF) on the menu you can control which pattern symbols will be used during the initial pattern search and during the refinement phase. The pattern symbols that can be used, are read from a file if the BI option is set, otherwise a default set will be used.
The default set has as the 20 first elements, the single amino acid symbols, and it also contains a set of ambiguous symbols, each containing amino acids that share some physio-chemical properties

In the file each symbol is given on a separate line concataining the letters that the symbol should match. For the example, only patterns with the symbols C and [DE] would be considered. During the initial search, pattern symbols corresponding to the first BN lines can be used.
default file is: Pratt.sets.big
Increasing BN will slow down the search and increase the memory usage, but allow more ambiguous pattern symbols.
The S option allows you to control the scoring of patterns. There are five possible scoring schemes to be used:
info: patterns are scored by their information content as defined in (Jonassen et al, 1995). Note that a pattern's score is independent of which sequences it matches.

mdl: patterns are scored by a Minimum Description Length principle derived scoring scheme, which is related to the one above, but penalises patterns scoring few sequences vs. patterns scoring many. Parameters Z0 to Z3 are required when this scoring scheme is used.
tree: a pattern is scored higher if it contains more information and/or if it matches more diverse sequences. The sequence diversity is calculated from a dendrogram which has to be input.
dist: similar to the tree scoring, except a matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree. The matrix has to be input.

ppv: a measure of Positive Predictive Value - it is assumed that the input sequences constitute a family, and are all contained in the Swiss-Prot database. PPV measures how certain one can be that a sequence belongs to the family given that it matches the pattern.
For the last three scoring schemes (tree, dist, ppv), an input file is needed.

Only patterns consistent with the alignment/matching the query sequence will be considered.

Using the E parameter you can adjust the greediness of the search. Setting E to 0 (zero), the search will be exhaustive. Increasing E increases the greediness, and decreases the time used in the search.

When the R option is switched on, patterns found during the initial pattern search are input to a refinement algorithm where more ambiguous pattern symbols can be added. For instance the pattern C-x(4)-D might be refined to C-x-[ILV]-x-D-x(3)-[DEF]

If the RG option is switched on, then ambiguous symbols listed in the symbols file (or in the default symbol set -- see help for option B), are used. If RG is off, only the letters needed to match the input sequences are included in the ambiguous pattern positions.
For example, if [ILV] is a listed allowed symbol, and [IL] is not, [IL] can be included in a pattern if RG is off, but if RG is on, the full symbol [ILV] will be included instead.

When switched on, patterns will be output in PROSITE style (for instance C-x(2,4)-[DE]). When switched off, patterns are output in a simpler consensus pattern style (for instance Cxx--[DE] where x matches exactly one arbitrary sequence symbol and - matches zero or one arbitrary sequence symbol).
Set the maximum number of patterns to be found by Pratt
Set the max. nr of patterns for which Pratt is to produce an alignment of the sequence segments matching it.

If the M option is set, then Pratt will print out the location of the sequence segments matching each of the (maximum 52) best patterns. The patterns are given labels A, B,...Z,a,b,...z in order of decreasing pattern score. Each sequence is printed on a line, one character per K-tuple in the sequence. If pattern with label C matches the third K-tuple in a sequence C is printed out. If several patterns match in the same K-tuple, only the best will be printed.
Sets the K value (ratio) used for printing the summary information about where in each sequence the pattern matches are found.
If set, the output is printed vertically instead of horizontally, vertical output can be better for large sequence sets.

comment.text: The S option allows you to control the scoring of patterns. There are five possible scoring schemes to be used:
info: patterns are scored by their information content as defined in (Jonassen et al, 1995). Note that a pattern's score is independent of which sequences it matches.

mdl: patterns are scored by a Minimum Description Length principle derived scoring scheme, which is related to the one above, but penalises patterns scoring few sequences vs. patterns scoring many. Parameters Z0 to Z3 are required when this scoring scheme is used.
tree: a pattern is scored higher if it contains more information and/or if it matches more diverse sequences. The sequence diversity is calculated from a dendrogram which has to be input.
dist: similar to the tree scoring, except a matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree. The matrix has to be input.

ppv: a measure of Positive Predictive Value - it is assumed that the input sequences constitute a family, and are all contained in the Swiss-Prot database. PPV measures how certain one can be that a sequence belongs to the family given that it matches the pattern.
For the last three scoring schemes (tree, dist, ppv), an input file is needed.

interface.label:
Scoring (-S)?
Information content (info) Minimum Description Length (mdl) Diversity calculated from a dendrogram (tree) Distances matrix (dist) Positive Predictive Value (ppv)
The S option allows you to control the scoring of patterns. There are five possible scoring schemes to be used:
info: patterns are scored by their information content as defined in (Jonassen et al, 1995). Note that a pattern's score is independent of which sequences it matches.
mdl: patterns are scored by a Minimum Description Length principle derived scoring scheme, which is related to the one above, but penalises patterns scoring few sequences vs. patterns scoring many. Parameters Z0 to Z3 are required when this scoring scheme is used.
tree: a pattern is scored higher if it contains more information and/or if it matches more diverse sequences. The sequence diversity is calculated from a dendrogram which has to be input.
dist: similar to the tree scoring, except a matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree. The matrix has to be input.
ppv: a measure of Positive Predictive Value - it is assumed that the input sequences constitute a family, and are all contained in the Swiss-Prot database. PPV measures how certain one can be that a sequence belongs to the family given that it matches the pattern.
For the last three scoring schemes (tree, dist, ppv), an input file is needed.

info: patterns are scored by their information content as defined in (Jonassen et al, 1995). Note that a pattern's score is independent of which sequences it matches.

mdl: patterns are scored by a Minimum Description Length principle derived scoring scheme, which is related to the one above, but penalises patterns scoring few sequences vs. patterns scoring many. Parameters Z0 to Z3 are required when this scoring scheme is used.
tree: a pattern is scored higher if it contains more information and/or if it matches more diverse sequences. The sequence diversity is calculated from a dendrogram which has to be input.
dist: similar to the tree scoring, except a matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree. The matrix has to be input.

ppv: a measure of Positive Predictive Value - it is assumed that the input sequences constitute a family, and are all contained in the Swiss-Prot database. PPV measures how certain one can be that a sequence belongs to the family given that it matches the pattern.
For the last three scoring schemes (tree, dist, ppv), an input file is needed.

parameter.name: treefile
parameter.prompt: Tree File for Scoring equal to tree (-SF)

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Tree File for Scoring equal to tree (-SF)

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

parameter.name: distfile
parameter.prompt: Distances File if Scoring equal to dist (-SF)

comment.text: A matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Distances File if Scoring equal to dist (-SF)

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: A matrix with pairwise the similarity between all pairs of input sequences are used instead of the tree.

parameter.name: uniprotdb
parameter.prompt: Swissprot file if Scoring equal to ppv (-SF)

comment.text: Default: uniprot_sprot databank.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Swissprot file if Scoring equal to ppv (-SF)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Default: uniprot_sprot databank.

format.code: ( "" , " -Z0 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Z0

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

format.code: ( "" , " -Z1 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Z1

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

format.code: ( "" , " -Z2 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Z2

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

format.code: ( "" , " -Z3 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

interface.label: Z3

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

format.code: ("" , " -G " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: If G is set to al or query, another option GF is required allowing the user to give the name of a file containing a multiple sequence alignment (in Clustal W format), or a query sequence in FastA format (without annotation). Only patterns consistent with the alignment/matching the query sequence will be considered.

interface.label:
Pattern Graph from: (-G)?
Sequence (seq) Alignment (al) Query
If G is set to al or query, another option GF is required allowing the user to give the name of a file containing a multiple sequence alignment (in Clustal W format), or a query sequence in FastA format (without annotation). Only patterns consistent with the alignment/matching the query sequence will be considered.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If G is set to al or query, another option GF is required allowing the user to give the name of a file containing a multiple sequence alignment (in Clustal W format), or a query sequence in FastA format (without annotation). Only patterns consistent with the alignment/matching the query sequence will be considered.

parameter.name: GF_ali
parameter.prompt: Alignment file (if G set to al) (-GF)

comment.text: Alignment file must be in CLUSTALW format

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Alignment file (if G set to al) (-GF)

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Alignment file must be in CLUSTALW format

parameter.name: GF_seq
parameter.prompt: Query sequence file (if G set query) (-GF)

comment.text: Query file must be in Fasta format

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Query sequence file (if G set query) (-GF)

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Query file must be in Fasta format

format.code: ("" , " -E " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Using the E parameter you can adjust the greediness of the search. Setting E to 0 (zero), the search will be exhaustive. Increasing E increases the greediness, and decreases the time used in the search.

interface.label:
Search Greediness (-E)?
Using the E parameter you can adjust the greediness of the search. Setting E to 0 (zero), the search will be exhaustive. Increasing E increases the greediness, and decreases the time used in the search.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Using the E parameter you can adjust the greediness of the search. Setting E to 0 (zero), the search will be exhaustive. Increasing E increases the greediness, and decreases the time used in the search.

comment.text: When the R option is switched on, patterns found during the initial pattern search are input to a refinement algorithm where more ambiguous pattern symbols can be added. For instance the pattern C-x(4)-D might be refined to C-x-[ILV]-x-D-x(3)-[DEF]

interface.label:
Pattern Refinement (-R)?
Yes No
When the R option is switched on, patterns found during the initial pattern search are input to a refinement algorithm where more ambiguous pattern symbols can be added. For instance the pattern C-x(4)-D might be refined to C-x-[ILV]-x-D-x(3)-[DEF]

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: When the R option is switched on, patterns found during the initial pattern search are input to a refinement algorithm where more ambiguous pattern symbols can be added. For instance the pattern C-x(4)-D might be refined to C-x-[ILV]-x-D-x(3)-[DEF]

parameter.name: RG
parameter.prompt: Generalise ambiguous symbols (if Pattern Refinement on) (-RG)

comment.text: If the RG option is switched on, then ambiguous symbols listed in the symbols file (or in the default symbol set -- see help for option B), are used. If RG is off, only the letters needed to match the input sequences are included in the ambiguous pattern positions.
For example, if [ILV] is a listed allowed symbol, and [IL] is not, [IL] can be included in a pattern if RG is off, but if RG is on, the full symbol [ILV] will be included instead.

interface.label:
Generalise ambiguous symbols (if Pattern Refinement on) (-RG)?
Yes No
If the RG option is switched on, then ambiguous symbols listed in the symbols file (or in the default symbol set -- see help for option B), are used. If RG is off, only the letters needed to match the input sequences are included in the ambiguous pattern positions.
For example, if [ILV] is a listed allowed symbol, and [IL] is not, [IL] can be included in a pattern if RG is off, but if RG is on, the full symbol [ILV] will be included instead.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If the RG option is switched on, then ambiguous symbols listed in the symbols file (or in the default symbol set -- see help for option B), are used. If RG is off, only the letters needed to match the input sequences are included in the ambiguous pattern positions.
For example, if [ILV] is a listed allowed symbol, and [IL] is not, [IL] can be included in a pattern if RG is off, but if RG is on, the full symbol [ILV] will be included instead.

comment.text: When switched on, patterns will be output in PROSITE style (for instance C-x(2,4)-[DE]). When switched off, patterns are output in a simpler consensus pattern style (for instance Cxx--[DE] where x matches exactly one arbitrary sequence symbol and - matches zero or one arbitrary sequence symbol).

interface.label:
PROSITE Pattern Format (-OP)?
Yes No
When switched on, patterns will be output in PROSITE style (for instance C-x(2,4)-[DE]). When switched off, patterns are output in a simpler consensus pattern style (for instance Cxx--[DE] where x matches exactly one arbitrary sequence symbol and - matches zero or one arbitrary sequence symbol).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: When switched on, patterns will be output in PROSITE style (for instance C-x(2,4)-[DE]). When switched off, patterns are output in a simpler consensus pattern style (for instance Cxx--[DE] where x matches exactly one arbitrary sequence symbol and - matches zero or one arbitrary sequence symbol).

format.code: ("" , " -ON " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Set the maximum number of patterns to be found by Pratt

interface.label:
Maximum number patterns (-ON)?
Set the maximum number of patterns to be found by Pratt

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the maximum number of patterns to be found by Pratt

format.code: ("" , " -OA " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Set the max. nr of patterns for which Pratt is to produce an alignment of the sequence segments matching it.

interface.label:
Maximum number Alignments (-OA)?
Set the max. nr of patterns for which Pratt is to produce an alignment of the sequence segments matching it.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the max. nr of patterns for which Pratt is to produce an alignment of the sequence segments matching it.

comment.text: If the M option is set, then Pratt will print out the location of the sequence segments matching each of the (maximum 52) best patterns. The patterns are given labels A, B,...Z,a,b,...z in order of decreasing pattern score. Each sequence is printed on a line, one character per K-tuple in the sequence. If pattern with label C matches the third K-tuple in a sequence C is printed out. If several patterns match in the same K-tuple, only the best will be printed.

interface.label:
Print Patterns in sequences (-M)?
Yes No
If the M option is set, then Pratt will print out the location of the sequence segments matching each of the (maximum 52) best patterns. The patterns are given labels A, B,...Z,a,b,...z in order of decreasing pattern score. Each sequence is printed on a line, one character per K-tuple in the sequence. If pattern with label C matches the third K-tuple in a sequence C is printed out. If several patterns match in the same K-tuple, only the best will be printed.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If the M option is set, then Pratt will print out the location of the sequence segments matching each of the (maximum 52) best patterns. The patterns are given labels A, B,...Z,a,b,...z in order of decreasing pattern score. Each sequence is printed on a line, one character per K-tuple in the sequence. If pattern with label C matches the third K-tuple in a sequence C is printed out. If several patterns match in the same K-tuple, only the best will be printed.

format.code: ("" , " -MR " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Sets the K value (ratio) used for printing the summary information about where in each sequence the pattern matches are found.

interface.label:
Ratio for printing (-MR)?
Sets the K value (ratio) used for printing the summary information about where in each sequence the pattern matches are found.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the K value (ratio) used for printing the summary information about where in each sequence the pattern matches are found.

comment.text: If set, the output is printed vertically instead of horizontally, vertical output can be better for large sequence sets.

interface.label:
Print vertically (-MV)?
Yes No
If set, the output is printed vertically instead of horizontally, vertical output can be better for large sequence sets.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If set, the output is printed vertically instead of horizontally, vertical output can be better for large sequence sets.
